My days of delight are no more,</br>Sweet moments of pleasure and peace;</br>The smile of the Morning is o'er,</br>And Night bids his horror increase.
The landscape, which smil'd to the view,</br>When Innocence gladden'd the day;</br>The flowrets which glitter'd with dew,</br>Alas!  are alike pass'd away.
'Twas Delia which made them look bright,</br>Her presence enlighten'd the scene;</br>Her absence had hid them in night,</br>For she of the plain was the Queen.
Yet ah!  how severe to my mind,</br>My folly has banish'd the Fair;</br>To her merit and worthiness blind,</br>I rightly am doom'd to despair.
Yet gentle's her bosom, I know,</br>How lovely and sweet to behold!</br>Tho' white as the fleece-fallen snow,</br>'Twas never, no, never, so cold.
Ye nymphs, and ye shepherds, come join,</br>With me the dear charmer implore,</br>Ah!  let her again but be kind,</br>And I shall be happy once more.</br>
